1. White light from the sun is a sum of all wavelengths of visible light. We perceive light at different wavelengths of the visible spectrum in colors.
2. Light as a wave can be reflected, refracted, or diffracted. Diffraction is a fancy way of saying a big wave goes through small slits and turns into many small waves.
3. The many small waves interfere with each other and boost some wavelengths while eliminating others (constructive/destructive interference). The resulting wavefront is reflected in some proportion back to your eyes.

Magnification is a function of the electron beam raster over the area of interest.  It doesn't magnify an image like a light microscope.  The quality of the image is a function of vacuum, carrying away the charge, the electronics to raster the beam and limiting the noise of the detector.   The gold carries away the electron charge.  If it wasn't there, the sample would charge and repel the electrons and just appear to glow.  There is no stitching of images.  It is an amazing instrument.

Strange to hear a scientifically literate youtuber say that we will never understand why a butterfly needs 'hairs' with a complex nanostructure. 100 years ago creationists questioned whether biologists could ever understand the use for a half developed wing, or an eye that can barely see. Yet we understand concepts like this in great detail just by running the evolutionary clock backwards, and recreating natural selection in our models. I could speculate that the nanostructure in the hairs is a direct result of the structure surrounding it having evolved, the pits on the wing being a precursor to the structure of the hairs. The pattern closely resembles the structure which the butterfly was already using on its wings, so it is easier for a dust particle from the wing to evolve into a small hair, retaining the same structure than it would be to start all over and create a hair in the way humans do (by stacking dead proteins). In fact, I'd be willing to bet that someone has already solved this problem. There is no problem that is beyond scientific inquiry, and given enough time we can solve almost all of them. Saying that we can never understand it is a cop out, and it immediately shuts down any real attempt at solving these problems.

I'm not a biologist, but I was a bit curious about the final question posed by the video, which is why there is such a complicated nano-structure for a certain part of the wing (6:44). The author seems to suggest that this is associated with incredible amounts of "information" or "energy", which is somehow excessive for its purpose.

But to me, there are many phenomena in nature that are associated with complicated structures (take snowflakes for instance). In many cases, these structures arise due to instabilities. Think of, for example, Rayleigh-Taylor (RT) instability where a smooth boundary is disrupted. But it's a silly point to say, "why does nature do such excessively complicated things with planar (or smooth) boundaries" in regards the RT instability.

Other examples include spot formation on animal coats. Although this might have been partly evolutionary, there are also mechanical and chemical reasons for spot formation due to instabilities (Turing instabilities for example). Again, it is false to propose that a smooth and unvarying coat is the 'natural' one. Nature tells us otherwise. The 'natural' coat may have patterns because this may be the stable configuration.

The main point I'm making is that the author suggests that somehow 'simplicity' (a smooth wing attachment, for instance) is somehow natural, whereas complexity is unnatural. I don't see any reason to assume this.

I'm bit disappointed with the colour. "Somehow" is not the explanation I was waiting for ;)
The colour of the reflected light from the wings is (probably) created by interference of light - similarly as colour of soap bubbles or oil stains on water surface is created. Yellow colour is separated from the light because of destructive interference given by phase difference of light reflected from different spots of the "baffled nanostructure".

Yes width of 575 nm would suggest constructive interference (enhancement) of the colour someone might concur - the phase difference would be in whole wavelengths. But what I think is this might be a bit of coincidence as the key dimension is length between those "tree branches" (different heights they are in) - if they are 1/4 of a wavelength apart (as from the picture in the video might be the case - if it is in scale) then light reflected from some branch travel just 1/2 of a wavelength shorter distance than light reflected from one just below it - and thus creating destructive interference - the light cancel itself out. Light of different wavelength have different phase difference and is not affected by the structure as much or at all.

I might be wrong, but that is what I was told some time ago and since I study optics (as PhD student) I do incline to such explanation. It does quite fit. - Maybe a motivation for further investigation. I dare you to prove me wrong ;)

Don't get me wrong, the scales on the butterflies' wings are beautifully efficient and highly complex, but so are the scales that constitute our skin. There is remarkably little difference between them, biochemically, and the functional difference reflects the difference in scales of the animals that use them. Hair, skin, horns, nails, feathers, butterfly scales, all share the same body of coding information, all tweaked by evolution to produce more efficient designs for a specific time, place, organism, and function.

So much energy and information goes into making such a beautiful butterfly, it is no surprise that we marvel at the beauty of butterflies.

Those "hairs" don't require a huge amount of energy and information, they just look like non-developed scales... which means it's actually less information ("grow what you already do, but stop in mid process") than it would require to grow a different structure (like an actual hair). Also they are highly repetitive structures in themselves, so not that much information required, nor actually much more energy than to grow a randomly organized one.

Those "hairs" I've got a suggestion. The scales are attached to a small pore, and they easily break off. It stands to reason the butterfly looses its scales continously, and eventually there'd be no more, that'd be bad for the butterfly.

Instead, what about if the scales grow back? Well how'd that work? I think the way it works is a bit like hairs on our head grow, but with an additional step. The scale is extruded from that pore, much like we extrude hair, but then when it's pushed out enough, it unfolds, kind of like a leaf.

So these hairs, they're scales in the making, that haven't yet unfurled.

We know insects have a respiratory system based on hollow tubes that bring oxygen to the tissue inside the animal, and on a flying insect one of the most efficent place to harvest oxygen is on the wings because of the convection produced by the animal itself.
